posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
IS SC necessary at all on such high magic a world? I would expect concealment to be readily available, at least as consumables giving Improved Invisibility access, in such an environment. Besides you already have empty body.

By giving SC up you free up 3 general feat slots (2 great dexes and armor skin, which means +3 AC, +1 AB) and 2 bonus rogue feat slots (crippling strike and skill mastery). For the rest, as said, go 12/8 preepic and go kama(s). I'd look into skill points allocation and get epic trap skills and possibly also into going Wis 8/Int 14 for extra skillpoints to pull off all the skills maxing necessary.

On the other side, if SC has to stay then empty body is redundant and mind immunity is probably replicated by gear in a high magic environment, so you could go for more rogue.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
SC V, ED builds can be very strong in high magic settings. With increasing magic it is easier to boost AC than AB. You can end up with a situation where you only hit on 20 rolls. In such a setting your opponent is not likely to roll a 20 more than once or perhaps twice per round if lucky, so ED will block most hits and SC will stop half of what is left ( can happen if you get swarmed). A high magic setting will also enchant your weapons so you get enough bonus damage to overcome the low base damage output from a dex build.
In a setting where you only hit on 20s, dualwielding without taking the feats is an option as it generates at least one extra attack. The low AB doesn't matter anymore since you hit on a 20 anyway.
SC V is far better than Improved invisibility since it cannot be dispelled, and everybody probably has items to cast dispel. If you have a wand of Improved invisibility that can be recharged, things are different, but you still have to spend time recasting the spell from the wand everytime you get dispelled.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
Ackkk... that stinkin' SD prereq! I knew there was some reason for taking them without WM but brain wasn't clicking on all cylinders. That's for the jump start, Kail!

Interesting to spawn another discussion of the merits of HiPS & SC.

True Seeing and Blind Fight will limit the usefulness of either, in my own experience. And in high magic, almost every skin has True Seeing property attached to it and items with that prop abound. The only way I have found SD all that useful is by virtue of SD 5 to grab the feats as HiPS itself is not all that great in PvP in general and on some servers worthless.

As far as Empty Body, never liked it. True, it can't be dispelled, but the duration and uses in limited rest is annoying. I tried it with a 30+ monk and was still disappointed. Seems to run out too quickly and you definitely can't keep it active while venturing or it will certainly expire when you need it most.

Wasting a dispel round on a charging IKD monk leaving stealth is a death sentence. Let them dispel at their leisure as they will be doing it while laying on their back.

As far as playing on a hit-on-20-roll only server, sry, can't be of much help with that other than, if that is true, then I would DEFINITELY try to reach the highest APR possible and that means flurry and ITWF. It's the best way to assure the highest number of opportunity for 20's. Also, it seems the server to be strongly biased towards a high-strength, high APR DevCrit build of some kind which would likely rule.

So the choice seems clear to me. The split will pay the price in terms of offensive capability being stuck with unarmed since it is too feat-starved to grab DWing feats while using SD as a tertiary. (yes, Mick, I agree that 2 of the DWing feats are not all that important, but unfortunately ITWF feat has prereqs. )

@campgod: KD is checked first based on AB (standard attack roll) with applicable size comparison effects and then against Discipline. IKD removes some of AB penalty and widens the scope of potential target size. In general, the larger and stronger the target Iike a dragon, for example), the more difficult (or impossible; with a caveat to custom races and morphed forms) to KD. High CON or fort saves never enters the picture.

That is one reason why Crippling Strike can be so effective in combo. Reduce the STR which then reduces the opposing Disc check.

Generally, in high-magic environments, unless you take lots of SD levels for DR, conceal & AC, the class itself has little value. You can bet than any PvP foe worth its salt will have some sort of character detection and blind fight active when they face any stealther.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
I wouldn't scrap the entire combo except the SD part seems to cost feat slots that are badly needed and with a poor return on investment. Rogue has such diverse epic feats that replacing SC5 with Empty Body (against bosses like Kail suggested and perhaps PvP) and those conceal scrolls would open up some more possibilities. If you can find/buy Ethereal Visage scrolls you can walk right through Evard's Tentacles without taking damage.

Whether a tertiary class is beneficial or not, well... let's consider that.
Possibilities: 1-4 Levels Ftr (WS/EWS + another feat), 1 Clc (late Spellcraft dump w/domains; bump WIS for spells), 1 Wiz (late Spellcraft dump, level 1 spells, familiar), 1 Rgr (FE, Trackless Step)

The Monk 21/Rogue 19 split is not bad at all as it stands. You'd be getting decent sneaks on a high APR, high speed, sneaky toon which is nothing to sneeze at. If what you are inferring about crit immunes not being that pervasive is true, then SA is a good option and perhaps Imp SA is the way to go. Otherwise, as usual for a dexer, damage is the main issue.

Once you have controlled the feat management you may want to consider halfling to gain AB & AC plus all the other lucky and sneaky race benefits. A DWing kama halfling will fight as good as or better than any medium race with this build (and totally immune to Evard's without any DR effect, as mentioned above for the elf).

Now to decide whether a different tertiary will add anything worthwhile without mucking up your feat schedule. Suggestions, team?

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
On one side True Seeing has been nerfed so I'm inclined to say that SD is a good tertiary. On the other it seems spot/listen can reach very high scores, but probably those can be countered by equivalently high scores in hide/ms (please campgod confirm the presence of hide/ms enhancing gear). I'd say that in such an environment one wants to get SF:hide/ms.

With scrolls of II easily available and that uber speed (made further uber by a perma/temporary haste) I'd safely drop SCV in favor of extra feats, as I detailed above. Even more so if wands of improved invisibility are available (wands cast faster than scrolls and are similarly uninterruptable and not counterable). One also has empty body to fall upon, just in case. Unarmed could be a good choice if one can get good gloves and a maxed wis to make good use of SF. On the other hand kama means an extra gear slot for enhancements, keen and is generally favored by high magic settings, unless the module builders take steps towards correcting the inherent disadvantage of gloves enchantments. Also, one can choose to dw even without the feats in a battle of 20s.

I'd consider going halfling using a single kama (deflect arrows vs archers, it's like a second ED vs ranged attacks) to get a further +1 AB/AC. The extra AB alone is more than enough to offset the loss of damage in unarmed strike and of single kama vs medium sized unarmed.

That's not the best of options with halfling. Halfling is a small race and hence you'll get a diminished unarmed damage in addition to giving up one gear slot (main hand). Using a single kama means the offhand is free to deflect arrows or to wield something like a holy symbol or other off hand (non weapon) piece of gear for extra enhancements. At the same time halfling small race grants +1 AB/+1 AC not counting towards any cap, which alone is more than enough to offset the lack of a offhand weapon, as said above.

The fact you are having difficulties knocking NPCs down is because as a halfling you are dual wielding kamas without even TWF. A very bad idea. That means -6 AB for both the main and the off hand, since kamas are not tiny weapons (which a halfling needs in the offhand to minimize penalties). Forget about dw kamas with a halfling unless you are locked in a battle of 20s.

campgod wrote:Dam a lot of good info I didnt even know about ty guys. So it looks like Halfling single Kama or elf and then DW? Not sure what would be better.
Halfling single wielding a kama has +1 AB/AC compared to elf (from small stature) and also +4 hide/ms checks in addition to a further +2 move silently. With a thrown weapon (darts, throwing axes, shurikens and slings) halfling gets a further +1 AB, from good aim. Elf has search/spot/listen boni together with perma active search and can get the 2 extra attacks per round from full dual wielding... which require a 3 feat investment (something you do not really have room for in the build). Me, I'd go with halfling, even if choosing unarmed in the end. Given the high magic environment, the differential in base damage is probably not really meaningful. The extra AB instead is.
